Oh really, Withheld? There's no housing shortage in NYC? What do you know about it in Lake Elmo, MN?

Have you ever met and talked with any homeless people in NYC? Yes, there are those who are seriously mentally ill and need care and compassion - not contempt.

Most of the rest ARE "like you and me" - at least, those of us who are not one of the .1%. Most of us are one or 2 paychecks away from being out on the street ourselves. Many of NYC's homeless people have jobs - did you know that? They just can't afford rent - even the most basic, small, shabby room.

I personally know several people who are highly at risk of becoming homeless - older people who lost their jobs and fall behind in their rent, and a few who had to give up their homes but were lucky enough to be taken in by relatives or friends. These are all formerly middle-class and upper-middle-class people.

But above all, people who are homeless are "like you and me" because they are human beings. People don't mutate into aliens when they lose their homes. But how they are viewed and treated by other people, by society, does change drastically, as your attitude shows.

If there are no homeless people in your town, the next time you're in the nearest city, try talking to a few of the homeless people you will inevitably see. At least, look them in the eyes, smile, wish them Merry Christmas and/or blessings in the new year. And bring a few sandwiches to offer. That's what He would do.
